About this file: This file is where all the text content within all the text pages is kept so that those files are more readable
about: Ocean water pollution is a serious problem that is caused by harmful things getting into Earth’s
oceans. These things are usually thrown, dumped or flow into the ocean instead of being taken care
of properly. They can come from many different sources such as people littering, factories or
boats. When the ocean water becomes polluted with plastic and chemicals it can cause harm to the
plants and animals that live there. This also makes the water dirty and unsafe for humans to use
Ocean water pollution has many negative effects on the ocean ecosystem. The pollutants can harm or
kill the sea creatures such as fish, turtles, dolphins and many more ocean creatures. Sometimes the
creatures in the ocean mistake rubbish for food and attempt to eat it which leads to them becoming
very sick. Pollution in the ocean can also kill a lot of marine plants such as coral and algae
which are underwater habits for many animals and help to produce a lot of the Earth’s oxygen. When
these plants are in unclean water or have their sunlight blocked by floating rubbish they can
disrupt the balance of the ocean around them making it harder for animals to survive.
It is important for all of us to take action when we can to help keep the ocean clean and spread
awareness about the issues that are related to unclean oceans. This can be begun by being mindful
of how our waste is disposed of both at home and in other places. We can also try to use less
plastic and reuse other items when possible. When we see litter around we can quickly pick it up
and put it into a bin to stop it from entering the environment and the ocean. By all doing our part
we can work together to make a big difference and make the world a better place.
causes: One of the major concerns in ocean water pollution is plastic entering the ocean. Plastic items
like bags, bottles and packaging often end up in the ocean when they are not treated properly on
land or bought when they are not needed. By not discarding plastic waste properly there is a very
high chance that it will either end up in the environment or in waterways. Once in waterways, it
will often be carried out to sea where it will stay for many years. Using bins to throw away
plastic waste will help to reduce the amount that ends up in waterways.
Microplastics are an indirect problem that is caused by plastic waste in the ocean. While they are
small and seem harmless they cause really big problems for animals and humans. They are created
when bigger pieces of plastic break down due to the elements into smaller pieces. These smaller
pieces then are in the water and can be drunk by animals or humans which can make them very sick.
Some products also contain microplastics in them. To reduce the amount of microplastics in the
ocean you can make sure to not use products that contain them and to also ensure you properly
dispose of waste.
Plastic utensils are a smaller cause of plastic pollution but one that many of us can take part in
to reduce the effect. Things like plastic straws, forks, knives and spoons along with plastic
takeout containers are really bad for the environment. As they are typically used when getting food
quickly to eat somewhere away from home a lot of the time there is no proper waste disposal nearby.
Alternates like paper, wood and bamboo are good because they are not harmful to the environment.
Also getting reusable utensils or saying no to getting utensils from restaurants when you know you
don’t need them can have a positive impact.
The fishing industry is also a really big contributor to ocean water pollution. If any of their
gear breaks out at sea or gets stuck on the bottom of the ocean it is cheaper for them to just
leave it in the ocean and get a new one than to try and recover it. Proper disposal of fishing
equipment and making sure to buy from suppliers that care about the environment can drastically
reduce the amount of pollution in the ocean due to fishing companies.
Waste management in general is also a massive issue. Australia does pretty well with waste
management but other countries in the world do not have good systems in place which leads to a lot
of waste that can be recycled not being recycled and other waste being handled poorly and ending up
in the environment. Governments and businesses can incorporate policies and practices that use more
sustainable materials and dispose of waste through better sources leading to a reduction in
pollution.
effects: Ocean water pollution is very bad for all marine life. Animals will mistake the plastic pollution
in the ocean for food and it will cause them to become sick. Other plastic pollution such as
fishing gear can cause marine life to be stuck until they eventually die of starvation. Plastic
pollution in the ocean disrupts the marine ecosystem, those natural habitats and the food chains in
this ecosystem leading to an imbalance in biodiversity which can cause other problems.
There are many negative impacts related to human health from ocean water pollution. As more
pollution enters the ocean and breaks down into microplastics, more of the water we drink contains
microplastics. The animals that are in the ocean are already being found to have much higher levels
of microplastics inside of them than 10 years ago. Around 1/3 of the world relies on seafood for
their protein and as this slowly contains higher levels of microplastics more people are beginning
to become sick.
The ecosystems themselves can be disrupted by there being plastic pollution in the ocean. Coral
reefs, kelp and areas of dense algae all provide food and shelter for many of the ocean's wildlife.
The plants will lose access to sunlight due to floating debris and the coral can become covered in
pollution. As these plants are essential to the ecosystems, once they begin to die the whole
ecosystem around them also begins to fall apart.
While many people think that ocean water pollution just affects the water and the animals that live
there, most people are not aware of the larger issue which is that the ocean produces at least 50%
of the Earth’s oxygen. This poses a much bigger risk than many people know of and this is why ocean
water pollution is one of the main problems we need to deal with in the world currently. Lower
oxygen levels will land ecosystems beginning to struggle and a decrease in the world’s air quality.
contribute: One of the best things that you can do to make a difference is to follow the three R’s. Reduce,
Reuse, Recycle. Reducing is when you decide that you don’t need that item so you choose not to get
it. This can be things like wanting the latest model of something when your current one works fine.
Reusing is deciding to use something you already have, such as a water bottle or food container
instead of throwing it out and getting a new one. If you have plastic waste that you can’t reuse
then you can recycle it. Check the label on the piece of plastic to find out if it can be recycled
in your local area. Lots of plastic bottles can be recycled with the return and earn scheme.
Saying “no” to unneeded plastic items such as plastic straws when you are out can help to reduce
the amount of plastic ending up in the ocean and becoming a danger to marine life. Instead, you can
carry around a reusable straw or just drink directly from the cup. Every time you say “no” to
receiving a piece of plastic cutlery you are reducing the amount of plastic ending up in landfills
and potentially the ocean.
Public cleanups are a great way to help out the environment. Local communities such as your school
or local council will periodically organise events where you clean up an area around you, sometimes
it is a park or other times it is somewhere on the harbour. If there are no public cleanups in your
area you can organise one through one of these communities. These cleanups help to keep the
environment clean, display the problems with not disposing of waste properly and limit the amount
of rubbish ending up in the ocean.
One of the best things you can do, especially if you are younger is to educate others around you
about the issue. By spreading awareness of the issue, more people will begin to make choices that
have a more positive impact on the environment and will lead to less plastic making its way into
the ocean. You can tell anyone you want about ocean water pollution even if you think they have
already heard about it because they may need a reminder or you may have some information that they
haven't heard yet.
